frameDefinitions: Two parties, the Exchangers, each give and receive from the other Themes.
A person (Speaker) expresses a Message or mental content, broadly understood, in a particular Manner.
A physical entity, construed as a point-Sound_source, emits a Sound.
A Speaker declares that they will no longer be involved with the Content.
This frame contains words for types of noise which can be used to characterize verbal communication.
The words in this frame describe Manners of verbal communication.
frameExamples: They <t>swapped</t> the island with the Neapolitan government of the day for the much smaller Capri.
That will only be possible if and when the IRA <t>renounces</t> armed struggle.
'Don't treat me as a child!' she <t>cried</t> scornfully.
listRoleDefinitions:
In cases where the <fen>Exchangers</fen> involved in a conversation are
construed as two separate groups with different levels of
volitionality or control, this role identifies the conversational
participant with greater semantic and syntactic prominence, as
compared with <fen>Exchanger_2</fen>. That is, <fen>Exchanger_1</fen> is generally
encoded as Subject, and peripheral FEs that do not make reference
to the event itself generally make reference to <fen>Exchanger_1</fen>. Thus
a <fen>Purpose</fen> (or <fen>Means</fen>, <fen>Depictive</fen>, or <fen>Manner</fen>) is construed to be that
of <fen>Exchanger_1</fen>, not necessarily that of <fen>Exchanger_2</fen> or the group
of <fen>Exchangers</fen> as a whole.

In cases where the <fen>Exchangers</fen> involved in a conversation are
construed as two separate groups with different levels of
volitionality or control, <fen>Exchanger_2</fen> refers to the semantically
and grammatically less prominent group. It is generally encoded
within a prepositional phrase (e.g. headed by with). Note that it
is possible for a single role to correspond to multiple referents.
For example, if the prepositional object in the example below were
plural, we would still assign it the single role <fen>Exchanger_2</fen>.

In some sentences both participants are expressed by the Subject, and there is no 'with'-phrase (cf example 1). In sentences like this, the Subject is assigned the role role <fen>Exchangers</fen>. In such sentences, the Subject always denotes more than one person, and it is understood that the reciprocal communication takes place between these two (or more) people. The Subject may denote two or more people either through conjunction, as in example 1, or through plurality, as in example 2, or by denoting a group, as in example 3. In each of these cases the role <fen>Exchangers</fen> is assigned. Notice that for nouns in the Exchange frame, it is possible for the <fen>Exchangers</fen> role to be expressed by a prepositional phrase as in example 4.
The item that begins in the possession of <fen>Exchanger_1</fen>.
The item that begins in the possession of <fen>Exchanger_2</fen>.
The items which change possession between the <fen>Exchangers</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the exchange takes place.
This role identifies the place where the exchange occurs.
<fen>Speaker</fen>, the person who encodes the <fen>Message</fen>, occurs as the External Argument of all the verbs:
The <fen>Message</fen> is almost invariably expressed in an NP Object. (The only exceptions occur with the verb <t>express</t>, which is occasionally used with that-clause complements.)

For most of the words in this frame, some expression of <fen>Manner</fen> or <fen>Medium</fen> is obligatory. As in other frames, <fen>Manner</fen> expressions characterize the action (in this case, the speech act performed by the <fen>Speaker</fen>). However, a wide range of <fen>Manner</fen> expressions occurs in this frame, including the following types:
<fen>Medium</fen> expresses the <fen>Medium</fen> of communication, such as the language used or the specific type of text in which the <fen>Message</fen> occurs:

The frame element <fen>Sound_source</fen> is assigned to a constituent referring to a physical entity which emits a sound. Such an entity must have an appropriately complex internal structure such that it can create a sound. For example, a machine or some other thing with moving parts can create sound by itself.

The frame element <fen>Sound</fen> is incorporated in the meaning of the verbs of this frame. Otherwise, this role is assigned to NPs which actually refer to a sound in the presence of the target. This typically occurs when the target is a verb used as a modifier in its <ment>-ing</ment> form, e.g.:
An event in which one or more <fen>Sound_source</fen>s participate and which is accompanied by <fen>Sound</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Noisy_event</fen> occurs.

The location of the <fen>Sound_source</fen>. This role differs from <fen>Location_of_source</fen> only in terms of point of view; the latter role implies a point of view that is not on the <fen>Sound_source</fen>.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the person who communicates their cessation of association with the <fen>Content</fen>.
The idea that the <fen>Speaker</fen> no longer associates with, whether it be an activity, a propostion, or a group.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the statement of renunciation.
The time when the statement is made.
The role specifies the place where the statement takes place.
<fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that delivers the <fen>Message</fen>.
Message has a number of different realizations in this frame, including <ment>that</ment>-clauses, direct quotes, infinitival complements, <ment>for-to</ment> phrases, and NP Objects.
<fen>Topic</fen> occurs in PP Complements, usually headed by <ment>about</ment>.
The <fen>Voice</fen> describes the <fex name=''>Speaker'</fex>s utterance or other message-encoded production.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> where the Communication noise event occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where an event occurs.
Speaker is the sentient entity that produces a Message or communicates about a Topic. It is expressed as the External Argument of verbs:
Addressee is the person to whom the Speaker  is communicating.  When expressed, the Addressee occurs as a PP Complement:
Message is the content which is communicated by the Speaker. The Message may be a direct quote, a finite complement clause or an NP Object:

Topic is the subject matter of the communicated Message.  It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by <ment>about</ment> and, in this frame, is frequently preceded by a quantificational noun which is treated as referring to the Message:
The time at which the communication event takes place.
The location at which the communication event takes place.
listRoleExamples: The trade <fex>with Cuba</fex> went exactly as planned.
<fex>Smithers and Kornfeldt</fex> traded Pez dispensers.
I tucked the pistol between my belt and tunic top (how I wish I had kept it, but I later swapped <fex>it</fex> with a Canadian for some cigarettes.
The organization bought the property in 1999, then swapped it with the BLM <fex>for about 100 parcels in 10 counties ranging in size from one to 920 acres</fex>.
They swapped <fex>guitars</fex>.
<fex>The teacher</fex> phrased the question carefully.
The Prime Minister expressed <fex>her sympathy for the victims</fex>.
True Manner: You should phrase it <fex>carefully</fex>.
Kim formulated her objections <fex>in French</fex>.
<fex>The wind</fex> howled.
The branches made a rattling <fex>sound</fex>.
<fex>The conversations</fex> droned on
It's going to beep again <fex>in two minutes</fex>.
A bat squeaked <fex>over our heads</fex>.
Bonnie Charlie then renounced <fex>his aspirations to the throne</fex>.
Castro renounced all involvement with the group <fex>over the radio</fex>.
<fex>Kim</fex> whined that it wasn't fair.
Kim whined <fex>that it wasn't fair</fex>.
Kim howled <fex>about the unfairness of it all</fex>.
<fex>John's voice</fex> bellowed for her to be quiet.
<fex>The boy</fex> mumbled an apology.
The taxi driver chattered away <fex>to me</fex> about gardening.
<fex>'I- It was an accident,'</fex> Jo stammered.
The actor chattered <fex>about the difficulties of being famous</fex>.
